A love letter to E_2-rings

Jun 6, 2019

Dear -rings/algebras/operads,

As you know, a lot of modern work in the area of structured ring spectra is dedicated to proving that certain spectra are -rings. There seem to be at least two reasons for why we care if a spectrum admits the structure of an -ring: one, it is more structure on an object, and having more structure can never be a bad thing; second, you get algebraic structure on the homotopy or homology of -rings which allows one to prove strong nonexistence results. Spectral algebraic geometry also uses -rings as the replacement for commutative rings.

It’s this last statement that I’d like to talk to you about in this post. There are a few levels of commutativity in spectra: homotopy commutative rings, -rings (!), -rings, etc. Using homotopy commutative rings as the basis for spectral algebraic geometry is not a very good idea; you can’t take limits of homotopy commutative rings and remain in the world of homotopy commutative rings (in particular, you can’t take global sections of sheaves on schemes defined in this manner). Working with -rings for is a good bet, though. This is the topic of John Francis’ thesis.

The lowest level of coherent commutativity one can reasonably impose on a ring spectrum is — surprise! — that of admitting the structure of an -ring. That’s where you come in. I’d like to believe that it is interesting to study a version of spectral algebraic geometry with you, -rings, as the replacement for commutative ring spectra, and regard having an -structure for as being extra structure on the -ring. I’ll abusively refer to this other kind of algebraic geometry as spectral algebraic geometry, with no -adornation. This seems like a good idea for a few reasons.

Here’s one. We said above that one of the reasons for liking spectra with an -algebra structure, where is a topological operad, is that it gives extra algebraic structure on the homotopy or homology of the spectrum. This algebraic structure comes in the form of power operations , where are the spaces in . One of the key power operations playing a role in modern chromatic homotopy theory is the lift of Frobenius coming setting and , so that . This is determined by an element of (or, more specifically, an element of ). But it turns out that one doesn’t need to go all the way up to the th space of the -operad: one already has in the cohomology of your th space. In particular, one can prove nilpotence theorems and nonexistence results.

Another motivation comes from the topic we’ve been discussing in a bunch of previous posts. Recall that a theorem of Hopkins and Mahowald shows that the Thom spectrum of the map detecting is ; in other words, the free -ring with is . According to the colloquial statement of the program sketched in the linked posts, the free --algebra with is . This is a strong structural result, and the precise form of the result is rather striking; we don’t just get a complex oriented ring of height — we get the initial complex oriented ring of height . In particular, the algebraic structure obtained from being an algebra over you, , is somehow enough to force strong rigidity in the spectral algebraic world.

The nail in the coffin, however, comes from the observation that if one considers algebraic geometry with -rings, multiple interesting examples of spectral schemes are simply thrown out. For instance, Ravenel’s spectra are known to be -rings but not -rings. The classical stack associated to is the moduli stack of formal groups with a chosen coordinate up to degree . Also featuring in the proof of nilpotence theorem is the -ring , and its action on the Thom spectrum of the subcomplex of . A long-term goal is to cast the proof of the nilpotence theorem in an algebro-geometric light, so having a spectral scheme corresponding to the -ring under consideration seems like a good idea.

Lots of love, and thanks for the ,

-- Sanath.

P.S. This discussion suggests a question: what are some results in either the purely algebro-geometric or purely chromatic aspects of spectral algebraic geometry which rely upon using the entire -ring structure?

Certainly the theory of power operations gives an example: Strickland has showed that the Morava -theory of is related to subgroups of the associated universal deformation formal group. Using Lurie’s work on elliptic cohomology (“tempered cohomology”), one can show that if is the global sections of an even periodic (-)refinement of a nice Deligne-Mumford stack, then the -cohomology of is related to -torsion points in the -divisible group associated to . I don’t know anything about -power operations on Morava -theory, though. It might be the case that interesting algebraic information is already visible in this case.
